A block on a horizontal, rough surface is connected to a hanging block by a string that passes over a pulley, as shown. The mass of the hanging block is greater than the mass of the block on the surface. The masses of the string and pulley are negligible, and the pulley can rotate with negligible friction around its axle. The string exerts a force <math alttext="T sub h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>h</mtext></msub></math> on the hanging block and a force <math alttext="T sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>s</mtext></msub></math> on the block on the surface. The hanging block accelerates until it reaches the ground and comes to rest. Which of the following correctly relates the magnitudes of the tensions <math alttext="T sub h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>h</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="T sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>s</mtext></msub></math> when both blocks are in motion and after the hanging block comes to rest?
